This game is a 4v1 cat-and-mouse that pits 1 killer (some original, some licensed), against 4 survivors (original/licensed), in a race for objective completion. Survivors are tasked with completing generators to power up the exit gates while avoiding the killer and helping each other to make it out alive. Killers are there to slow down their progress and stop them from leaving in order to make sacrifices to The Entity. 

To facilitate gameplay variety, each killer has their own unique powers. Additionally, there are perks that modify abilities and change gameplay, and every character has "teachable" perks. As an example, some survivor perks allow you to run very quickly for a few seconds, or to heal yourself without a medkit. Some killer perks allow you to see the auras of survivors for a few seconds when you hook a survivor, or to have crows tattle on survivor locations. So if you like a perk from Survivor A, but want to play as Survivor X, you can do that as long as you level up Survivor A and unlock the teachable perk. This same concept of teachable perks applies to killers. 

As with all competitive vs games, there are salty people. There are people who actually think teabagging is funny. There are people who overuse the word "toxic". There are people who don't understand logic and blame everyone else for losses.
That being said, this game is still a lot of fun, as long as your definition of "winning" isn't the traditional "Got out alive/Killed all 4 survivors". If you play for fun, you're probably gonna have fun. If you play to say "I'm a rank 1", you're going to become jaded very quickly. 
Every game is a GG for someone. You aren't required to participate in the post-game chat, but spilling salt doesn't really help anyone. Take the W or the L and move on to the next match. 

See you in the fog! (I'll probably be on a hook hoping my team makes it out alive. ;) )

Theres still a bug in the game from beta where when loading into a match you randomly crash. They have characters that directly target phobias (Clown, Vomit) to which they stated they would not add, the game is basically Pay to Fee you pay the base game price and then for ever time you want to play a non bottom tier killer you have to give them $10. I still play it I still bought a bunch of stuff for it but I dont recommend it

This game needs only two things to make it an excellent one: 

1. Fix the matchmaking, because
2. The wait times for games are too damn long. I hate waiting 10+ minutes as a killer only to have my face kicked in by a 4-man Survivor With Friends who're ten levels higher than me AND on Discord comms who proceed to dance around me all game. 

Other than that, solid core concept. Bit Pay2Win, though, but eh. Buy it on sale, that's what I did.

The game itself is fun when single player. Playing with others definitely makes it better. I would recommend having a couple friends play with you and be ready to die a lot. The only draw backs would always be the micro transaction. It would be better if you could unlock the clothes without having to pay more money into the game.
Muy buen juego divertido, tanto de los 2 lados Superviviente y Asesino

The game has spiraled downward year after year patch after patch. Fundamentally the game will never be balanced for competitive play but the devs seem to care only about the microscopic tournament scene and refuse any changes towards making the game more fun.

Pretty simply scummy behaviors like camping are outright encouraged by the devs as "skill expression" and there are no systems in place to encourage more engaging gameplay

I have many mixed feelings about DBD. At the time of writing this I have over 400 hours in the game and made it to Red Ranks playing survivor and purple ranks playing killer. Overall, I would recommend dbd to most players looking for a fun game to play alone or with friends. However, there are many flaws with this game as well. 

     The game is mostly balanced in my opinion for both killers and survivors but there are things that can be done on both sides to make the game less than fair. For example, survivors usually have a hard time going against killers with high ping because it can cause some rather questionable hits on survivors. On the other hand, survivors can make the game unfair for the killer by coordinating their efforts in a call or bringing many of the same perks or items that can cause a rather unfair advantage. There is also the toxicity factor of this game. While this game is not the most toxic out there, it is definently one of them. I would not recommend dbd to anyone looking for a non-toxic experience. These are all negative, but probably the worst thing about this game is the way that the developers treat the community. I think most of my fellow players can agree that the devs are very stubborn, and rarely take any community input into consideration. 

     In conclusion, even though this game has its flaws I believe the positives outweigh the negatives in this game. I have had a blast playing this game and I don't intend to stop playing it anytime soon!
